title: Ticket #422: Fetch hook broken on Windows.
description:
From: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=497895

Description of problem:

A simple fetch hook that does "exit 0" on Windows will run a number of times and then block the startd. The result is the startd is killed and restarted by the master, which starts the cycle again. While hung the startd does not advertise itself and is not responsive to condor_status -direct.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):

7.2.2

How reproducible:

100%

Additional info:

  • It is presume that this is related to pipe closing code, and potentially fast pid re-use on Windows. It may also be a timing problem, wherein the hook exists, closes its fds before the call to DaemonCore::PidEntry::pipeFullWrite(), with then fails.

  • Looks like Ian Chesal and friends on condor-users have gathered up additional information on this problem (or a very closely related one).
remarks:
2009-May-14 12:28:36 by burnett:
Problem break down:

  • Fetch Work code creates a HookClient object with pipes to capture input, output, etc. if requested. The fact that it creates a pipe to capture stdin is most important to us.
  • The registration of the stdin pipe calls PipeEnd::set_registered() and PipeEnd::set_watched(); which is to say, the pid watching code in daemonCore will monitor the pipe's state.
  • The pipe watching code, now in control, first calls ReadPipeEnd::pre_wait() to "simulate the semantics of select" by starting asynchronous reading on the pipe (returning an event hadle that can be monitored for a signal--used in place of a process or thread handle by the pid watcher).
  • This is quickly followed by a call to ReadPipeEnd::post_wait() which finishes any outstanding i/o and sets a signal to reflect the fact that it is no longer managed by the pid watcher.
  • At this point, we see the hook client completing its work (signals are handled before pipes, but in this case, the signal is dispatched after the signal handling has been done [so it gets caught on the next pump of DaemonCore::Driver()).
  • Instead of the pipes being cleaned up at this point, we see a call to ReadPipeEnd::io_ready(), wich returns true since by this point all reading is complete. Unfortunately, at this point in the code this return value is interpreted as if to mean that the pipe is also ready to be read from. (The semantics of this seem broken in this case, as it seems this call now has a double meaning: i.e. that no, there is no outstanding i/o or an error, and that yes, this pipe can continue to be read from [even if the pipe has signaled to pid watcher and told it that there is nothing left to read.].)
  • Since the state of the ReadPipeEnd object contains no error (because the ReadPipeEnd::post_wait(), called above, succeeds), another call to the pipe handler is performed, due to the ReadPipeEnd::io_ready() returning the affirmative.
  • After the pipe handler is called in DaemonCore::Driver() the pipe is once again added to the pid watcher, since the pipe has not been closed by its handler.
  • Finally, the process reaper calls the pipe handler one last time and tries to close the pipe. This close attempt calls pipeHandler(), then DaemonCore::Close_Pipe(), then DaemonCore::Cancel_Pipe(), which hangs on PipeEnd::cancel() because it is still being watched by the pid watcher thread.

2009-May-14 12:31:15 by burnett:
To reproduce the problem, add the following condor_config entries: 

  STARTD_JOB_HOOK_KEYWORD = BROKEN
  BROKEN_HOOK_DIR = c:/condor/hooks
  BROKEN_HOOK_FETCH_WORK = $(BROKEN_HOOK_DIR)/fetch.bat
  FETCHWORKDELAY = 0

Where fetch.bat contains one line: 

  @exit 0

Restart Condor and tail the startd log file.

2009-Aug-14 12:31:15 by rrati:

The [14601] changes breaks job hooks in the startd/starter for hooks that are started, but not really cared about (reply & status hooks). The startd/starter fires off those hooks but doesn't care about the output of the hook. With [14601], the stdin pipe is being closed when the HookClient is deleted which prevents the data actually making it to the hook's stdin.

Should we should roll back the changes from this commit?

2009-Aug-14 17:09:29 by tannenba:
Hi Rob! Couple quick questions w/o fully context switching to look at the code involved and swapping back in all the context needed to be authoritative, so sorry if these questions are ignorant:

  1. Without looking closely at the code, if we revert [14601], aren't handles/descriptors being leaked?

  2. How does data not making it to the stdin of the hook "break" the hook? Shouldn't the hook just go away if stdin is closed out on it before it can read what it needs?

2009-Aug-17 08:51:55 by rrati:
1) As I was looking into what was happening with the hooks, I was noticing that without the changes in #422 it looked like fds were being leaked in the reply hook case. It's likely the same story with the status hook as well. I also need to dig into the fd situation more in these cases.

2) Data not making it to the hook "breaks" the hook from the usability perspective. If no data makes it to the hook stdin, then any hook that relies on that data will no longer work. The documentation calls out the data that should be available to the hooks in their stdins and without that data, there's really no way to tell which job a hook is being called for.

2009-Aug-17 09:00:36 by tannenba:
While I am sympathetic to the hook usability factor, I guess the leaking of resources by daemons/services worries me more. Seems like we need to dig a bit deeper before simply reverting [14601]. Thanks.

2009-Aug-17 10:01:12 by rrati:
File descriptors are not being leaked. pipeFullWrite will close the stdin pipe when all data has been written to the stdin pipe or there is an error writing to the pipe. All job hooks have data passed to the stdin, so there is no need to close the stdin pipe in any other place. All the changes for #422 should be reverted.

2009-Aug-17 10:17:20 by tannenba:
Right then. [14601] reverted.

2009-Sep-04 09:51:20 by ichesal:
Bump. Any updates on this guys? I've got about 1 more week where I can hold out and then...well...I'm looking at a full system re-architect. We bet the farm on hooks working in 7.2.x. Thanks.

2009-Sep-15 14:51:13 by pmackinn:
Reproducibility notes:

  • Multi-core seems more immune to problems (I have an 8-way box) to the point where my test hook will randomly render the expected output. In other words, pipes can get closed (not just stdin) before the fetched hook job is completed.

  • NUM_CPUS = 1 with default logging and a 30 sec fetch rate has things running smoothly save for one empty hook output out of 300.

  • As Ben noted, everything gets stuck in PipeEnd::cancel() even though I have tried to cancel the pipe whenever we hit EINVAL inside pipeWriteFull.

2009-Sep-15 17:31:08 by pmackinn:
Testing update:

  • USE_PROCD = False and NUM_CPUS = 1 increases stability further. Fetch jobs were continuously processed for 2 hours and startd was not hung on master shutdown.

2009-Oct-15 18:17:13 by tannenba:
Think I found the problem: a deadlock between the startd main thread and daemonCore pidwatcher thread. Pushed a patch to V7_4_0-branch. Startd seems much happier now with job hook on Win32.

2009-Oct-16 09:51:52 by pmackinn:
The hang seems to be fixed. However, I still see some empty fetch output files in my test on an 8-way XP box. My test is a simple perl script that outputs a job ad to invoke ipconfig.exe.

I vary my test configuration using combinations of these values:

#USE_PROCD = False
#PRIVSEP_ENABLED = False
#NUM_CPUS = 1...8
#FetchWorkDelay = ifThenElse(State == "Claimed" && Activity == "Idle", 0, 30)

As you increase the number of CPUs there is an increased likelihood of seeing an empty output file (say above 4 slots).

2009-Oct-16 14:09:30 by tannenba:
Hi pmackinn --

I don't know what you are talking about re your above remark. What precisely do you mean by "I still see some empty fetch output files" ?

Do you mean that your fetch hook writes to stdout but that is not picked up by the startd?
